lines.text: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, BENEDICK, BEATRICE, MARGARET, URSULA, FRIAR FRANCIS, and HERO

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: Did I not tell you she was innocent?

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: So are the prince and Claudio, who accused her Upon the error that you heard debated: But Margaret was in some fault for this, Although against her will, as it appears In the true course of all the question.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Well, I am glad that all things sort so well.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: And so am I, being else by faith enforced To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Well, daughter, and you gentle-women all, Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves, And when I send for you, come hither mask'd. The prince and Claudio promised by this hour To visit me. You know your office, brother: You must be father to your brother's daughter And give her to young Claudio.
Exeunt Ladies

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Which I will do with confirm'd countenance.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Friar, I must entreat your pains, I think.

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: To do what, signior?

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: To bind me, or undo me; one of them. Signior Leonato, truth it is, good signior, Your niece regards me with an eye of favour.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: That eye my daughter lent her: 'tis most true.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: And I do with an eye of love requite her.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: The sight whereof I think you had from me, From Claudio and the prince: but what's your will?

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Your answer, sir, is enigmatical: But, for my will, my will is your good will May stand with ours, this day to be conjoin'd In the state of honourable marriage: In which, good friar, I shall desire your help.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: My heart is with your liking.

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: And my help. Here comes the prince and Claudio.
Enter DON PEDRO and CLAUDIO, and two or three others

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Good morrow to this fair assembly.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Good morrow, prince; good morrow, Claudio: We here attend you. Are you yet determined To-day to marry with my brother's daughter?

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: I'll hold my mind, were she an Ethiope.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Call her forth, brother; here's the friar ready.
Exit ANTONIO

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Good morrow, Benedick. Why, what's the matter, That you have such a February face, So full of frost, of storm and cloudiness?

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: I think he thinks upon the savage bull. Tush, fear not, man; we'll tip thy horns with gold And all Europa shall rejoice at thee, As once Europa did at lusty Jove, When he would play the noble beast in love.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Bull Jove, sir, had an amiable low; And some such strange bull leap'd your father's cow, And got a calf in that same noble feat Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: For this I owe you: here comes other reckonings. Which is the lady I must seize upon?
Re-enter ANTONIO, with the Ladies masked

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: This same is she, and I do give you her.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Why, then she's mine. Sweet, let me see your face.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: No, that you shall not, till you take her hand Before this friar and swear to marry her.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Give me your hand: before this holy friar, I am your husband, if you like of me.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: And when I lived, I was your other wife: And when you loved, you were my other husband.
Unmasking

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Another Hero!

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: Nothing certainer: One Hero died defiled, but I do live, And surely as I live, I am a maid.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: The former Hero! Hero that is dead!

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: She died, my lord, but whiles her slander lived.

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: All this amazement can I qualify: When after that the holy rites are ended, I'll tell you largely of fair Hero's death: Meantime let wonder seem familiar, And to the chapel let us presently.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Soft and fair, friar. Which is Beatrice?

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: [Unmasking]  I answer to that name. What is your will?

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Do not you love me?

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Why, no; no more than reason.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Why, then your uncle and the prince and Claudio Have been deceived; they swore you did.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Do not you love me?

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Troth, no; no more than reason.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Why, then my cousin Margaret and Ursula Are much deceived; for they did swear you did.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: They swore that you were almost sick for me.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: 'Tis no such matter. Then you do not love me?

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: No, truly, but in friendly recompense.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: And I'll be sworn upon't that he loves her; For here's a paper written in his hand, A halting sonnet of his own pure brain, Fashion'd to Beatrice.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: And here's another Writ in my cousin's hand, stolen from her pocket, Containing her affection unto Benedick.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: A miracle! here's our own hands against our hearts. Come, I will have thee; but, by this light, I take thee for pity.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: I would not deny you; but, by this good day, I yield upon great persuasion; and partly to save your life, for I was told you were in a consumption.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Peace! I will stop your mouth.
Kissing her

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: How dost thou, Benedick, the married man?

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: I'll tell thee what, prince; a college of wit-crackers cannot flout me out of my humour. Dost thou think I  care for a satire or an epigram? No: if a man will be beaten with brains, a' shall wear nothing handsome about him. In brief, since I do purpose to marry, I will think nothing to any purpose that the world can say against it; and therefore never flout at me for what I have said against it; for man is a giddy thing, and this is my conclusion. For thy part, Claudio, I did think to have beaten thee, but in that thou art like to be my kinsman, live unbruised and love my cousin.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: I had well hoped thou wouldst have denied Beatrice, that I might have cudgelled thee out of thy single life, to make thee a double-dealer; which, out of question, thou wilt be, if my cousin do not look exceedingly narrowly to thee.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Come, come, we are friends: let's have a dance ere we are married, that we may lighten our own hearts and our wives' heels.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: We'll have dancing afterward.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: First, of my word; therefore play, music. Prince, thou art sad; get thee a wife, get thee a wife: there is no staff more reverend than one tipped with horn.
Enter a Messenger

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: My lord, your brother John is ta'en in flight, And brought with armed men back to Messina.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Think not on him till to-morrow: I'll devise thee brave punishments for him. Strike up, pipers.
Dance
Exeunt
